titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Papers of Elizabeth Strauss Plaut(1910-2003)
1738-2006
AR 25309 / MF 932
titlestmt.author: Processed by Dianne Ritchey Oummia

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from ElizabethStraussPlaut.xml

profiledesc.creation: Electronic finding aid was encoded in EAD 2002 by Dianne Ritchey Oummia inJuly 2008.

change.item: encoding of linking to digital objects from finding aid was changed from <extref> to <dao> through dao_conv.xsl
Added links to digital objects for oversized materials in Container List.

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: This collection contains the genealogical research of Elizabeth Strauss Plaut. Papers to be found here include extensive correspondence, family trees, and research notes on the genealogy of the Plaut and Strauss families.
did.langmaterial: The collection is primarily inEnglishwith someGermanandHebrew.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Elizabeth Strauss was born on October 12, 1910 in New York City, the second child of Harry Strauss and Therese Abraham Strauss. A few years after the birth of his daughter Harry Strauss died of typhoid fever, and Therese Strauss relocated with her children to her family home in Cincinnati, where the family resided with her parents, Victor and Emma Abraham.

Elizabeth Strauss attended the University of Cincinnati, where she majored in zoology. While continuing to study for her teacher's certificate, she met W. Gunther Plaut, a recent immigrant from Germany who was studying at the Hebrew Union College. They were married on November 10, 1938.

The following September the couple moved when Gunther Plaut became assistant rabbi of the Washington Boulevard Temple in Chicago. There Elizabeth Plaut started a Judaica shop in addition to her duties as rebbetzin. In 1942 the couple had a son. The family moved several times due to Gunther Plaut's various assignments as a chaplain in the U.S. Army during World War II. After a return to Chicago, where the family expanded to include a daughter, they moved to St. Paul, Minnesota, when Gunther Plaut became rabbi at the Mount Zion Hebrew Congregation. The family remained there for thirteen years. During this time Elizabeth Plaut was also very active as the rabbi's wife. In addition, in 1952 she created "Holiplay," a children's game about the Jewish holidays. Finally, the family made its last relocation when Gunther Plaut became rabbi for the Holy Blossom Temple in Toronto, Ontario, a much larger congregation than that in St. Paul.

It was during the early 1970s that Elizabeth Plaut became involved in documenting the genealogy of the Strauss, Plaut, and related families. Over the following three decades she accumulated numerous family trees and voluminous research on the family history, collecting information from family members as well as print sources and archival records. This work culminated in the publication of articles in genealogical periodicals such asSearchandToledot, as well as in three books.
Elizabeth Strauss Plaut died on September 13, 2003 (16 Ellul 5763).

chronitem.event: Guggenheim/ Wormser Family: a Genealogical 300-Year Memoir
Gumprichs of Münster/ Westphalia: a Tale of Four Continents
Plaut Family: Tracing the Legacy (with Jonathan V. Plaut as editor and an introduction and additional research by Karen S. Franklin)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Elizabeth Strauss Plaut collection holds the genealogical research that culminated in the production of three books,Gumprichs of Münster/ Westphalia: a Tale of Four Continents,Guggenheim/ Wormser Family: a Genealogical 300-Year Memoir, andPlaut Family: Tracing the Legacy.

Nearly all of the series in this collection consist of extensive genealogical correspondence, family trees, and research notes, with most folders holding family trees or notes on family trees.Series Iholds research on the Plaut family, with much of it divided by the location in Germany from which the family derived. In addition, this series also includes material on the Gumprich and Rosenthal families, related to the genealogy of Selma Gumprich Plaut. Genealogy on the Strauss family will be found inSeries II, and consists of research into many branches of the family tree; the most prominent branches of the family loosely form the basis for subseries within Series II, including theAbraham, Strauss,Guggenheim/ Wormser,Wertheimer,Wisebart,Kline,Rauh, Mack, andDreyfoosfamilies. General genealogical research, or research whose branch was not clearly identified by Elizabeth Strauss comprisesSeries III: General and Unsorted Genealogical Files. Oversized family trees of both Plaut and Strauss ancestors are included inSeries IV. Papers pertaining to the writing or publishing of Elizabeth Strauss' books make upSeries V, and include drafts of her books on the Gumprich and Guggenheim/ Wormser families as well as some correspondence with publishers.

Photographs and copies of photographs of family members are often included with the correspondence or collected material on family branches. However, some of these types of material were not included among the genealogical files, and these primarily formSeries VI. In addition to photographs, this series holds a few other papers of visual material.

Files unrelated to genealogical research formSeries VII. Included here is one folder of personal correspondence, drafts of Elizabeth Strauss Plaut's creative writing and texts for lectures and other public addresses.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in six series:

item.ref: Series I: W. Gunther Plaut Genealogy, 1738-2006
Series II: Elizabeth Strauss Plaut Genealogy, 1847-1999
Series III: General and Unsorted Genealogical Files, 1950-1999
Series IV: Oversized Family Trees, undated

Series VII: Non-Genealogical Material, 1940s-2001
Subseries 1: Writings, Correspondence, and Notes, 1940s-2001
Subseries 2: Collected Material, 1969-1998

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The LBI Archives also hold a related collection, the Elizabeth Plaut Collection(AR 10087).

The LBI Library has two of Elizabeth Strauss Plaut's books:
The Gumprichs of Muenster/Westphalia: a Tale of Four Continents(st 427)
The Guggenheim/Wormser family: a Genealogical 300-Year Memoir(CS 629 G84 P53 1996)

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Some photographs have been removed to the LBI Photograph Collection.

accessrestrict.head: Access Information
accessrestrict.p: Readers may access the collection by visiting theLillian Goldman Reading Roomat the Center for Jewish History. We recommend reserving the collection in advance; please visit theLBI Online Catalogand click on the "Request" button.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
There may be some restrictions on the use of the collection. For more information, contact:
Leo Baeck Institute, Center for Jewish History, 15 West 16th Street, New York, NY 10011
email:lbaeck@lbi.cjh.org

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); Elizabeth Strauss Plaut Collection; AR 25309; box number; folder number; Leo Baeck Institute.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Much of the arrangement of this collection was based on the original order of the papers. See individual series descriptions for more detailed comments on the organization of series and subseries and naming of folders.

did.unittitle: Series I: W. Gunther Plaut Genealogy
did.langmaterial: The series is primarily inEnglishwith someGermanandHebrew

arrangement.p:
Divided into three subseries:
Subseries 1: Locations
Subseries 2: Other Research Material
Subseries 3: Gumprich and Rosenthal Families

scopecontent.p: Series I consists of papers created during Elizabeth Strauss Plaut's genealogical research on the Plaut family. It primarily includes research on the Plaut (Blaut/ Blout/ Plauth) family and the related Gumprich and Rosenthal families. This is the largest area of the collection, constituting more than half of it. Much of the arrangement was derived from observation of Elizabeth Plaut's own original arrangement. This original order consisted of five linear feet of material organized by locations of towns in Germany, and one foot of material on the Gumprich and Rosenthal families, as well as approximately two additional feet of research material on the Plaut family with less organization.

Much of the papers that comprise this series are of a similar nature. Included is correspondence with numerous relatives and research institutions on the family genealogy. The correspondence with relatives very often also mentions family news and events and sometimes includes photographs of family members. Other papers found here include extensive family trees, copies of historical records or extracts from published sources concerning family members, as well a large number of notes on the family genealogy.

arrangement.p:
Subseries 1 is separated by location, as follows:
A) Falkenberg and Felsenberg (Dannenberg Family)
B) Frankershausen
C) Frielendorf
D) Geisa
E) Gudensberg and Obervorschuetz
F) Ottrau
G) Rauschenberg
H) Reichensachsen
I) Rotenburg an der Fulda
J) Schenklengsfeld
K) Schmalkalden
L) Wehrda
M) Willingshausen
N) Other Locations

scopecontent.p: Subseries 1 is comprised of genealogical research files on the Plaut family arranged by location, following the observed original order. The locations appear to represent the areas in Germany (primarily towns in Hesse and Thuringia) from which the various branches of the family stemmed. Although the location sections have been arranged alphabetically by the name of the area for ease of use, all files originally placed together and marked as belonging to a specific location have not been separated from other files within that location. Some locations with fewer files were originally found in generally alphabetic order; these comprise the section"Other Locations."Within each location, folders predominantly comprised of similar formats, such as correspondence, notes, or family trees, have been grouped together during processing for ease of use, although users should note that most folders within this subseries include family trees or notes on family trees. Folder titles follow the original title of folders provided by Elizabeth Strauss Plaut. Any information provided within a file by Elizabeth Strauss Plaut as to the content of the file has been retained in this finding aid; folders with extensive correspondence include lists of correspondents in the finding aid. Folders originally entitled with an individual's name that hold research about a specific family member's branch of the family tree include the phrase "branch" in the folder title in order to differentiate such papers from files on specific individuals.

Papers in this subseries primarily include extensive family trees and correspondence, although research notes and photocopies of historical or archival records or clippings pertaining to family members are also located here.

Elizabeth Strauss Plaut maintained correspondence spanning more than three decades with numerous individuals while pursuing research on the Plaut family. Family members were largely located in the United States and Israel, but also include family in Europe, Canada, South Africa, Japan, and South America. While the correspondence clearly focuses on genealogical research, it also mentions family news and events and other personal topics. A few photographs or photocopies of photographs may be found among the research material. In addition, several memoirs are also located within this subseries; those ofClara PlautandBertel Borowskydescribe their experiences during World War II and the Holocaust years, while the memoir ofMarjorie Hessdiscusses the family history and significant family events. In addition to family correspondence, some letters within this subseries are with archives or historical societies and include Elizabeth Strauss Plaut's requests for information or photocopies of records from these institutions.

did.langmaterial: This subseries is primarily inEnglishwith someGerman.

arrangement.p: Divided intoCorrespondence;Notes, Family Trees, and Collected Documentation; and files originally leftUnsorted.

scopecontent.p: Subseries 2 holds the research files pertaining to the Plaut family that were not originally ordered by location. During processing these files were grouped together by document genre and files Elizabeth Strauss Plaut left unsorted. Untitled folders or those labeled "various" were assigned titles during processing.

Correspondence found in this subseries is with family members and research institutions concerning the genealogy of the Plaut family. Letters between Elizabeth Strauss Plaut and family members additionally contain personal information on family members and events. Other papers found in this subseries include family trees and notes concerning the research into the Plaut family, as well as some photocopies of records pertaining to Plaut ancestors. Clippings on several members, including Elizabeth Plaut's husband and son, will also be found among the papers of this subseries. Amemoirfrom an unidentified member of the Ornstein family includes reminiscences of time spent in concentration camps.

scopecontent.p: Subseries 3 is comprised of files originally located together and labeled as pertaining to the Gumprich and Rosenthal families. These families appear to have been related to one another, and were connected to the Plaut family via W. Gunther Plaut's mother, Selma Gumprich Plaut. Folder titles were derived from those originally given by Elizabeth Strauss Plaut; folders were arranged alphabetically during processing.

This subseries primarily holds correspondence on the genealogy of the Gumprich and Rosenthal families as well as family trees and some notes. Much of the correspondence also includes personal details about family members. Some drafts, notes, receipts, and correspondence relating to the publishing of Elizabeth Plaut's book,The Gumprichs of Münster/ Westphalia: a Tale of Four Continentswill also be found among the papers here. Information on the Rosenthal porcelain company is also available in this subseries.

Series II: Elizabeth Strauss Plaut Genealogy

arrangement.p:
Divided into seven subseries by family branch:
Subseries 1: Abraham/ Strauss
Subseries 2: Dreifus/ Dreyfus/ Dreyfoos
Subseries 3: Kline
Subseries 4: Rauh/ Mack
Subseries 5: Wertheimer
Subseries 6: Wisebart
Subseries 7: Wormser/ Guggenheim

scopecontent.p: Series II holds research into the ancestors of Elizabeth Strauss Plaut, and chiefly involves material on the Guggenheim/Wormser, Abraham, Strauss, Dreyfoos, Kline, Wisebart, Wertheimer, Rauh, and Mack families. During processing, these families were seen to have the largest volume of files. The prominent volume of material on these branches of the family, along with Elizabeth Plaut's notations, served as the basis for the creation of seven subseries.

Any information provided by Elizabeth Strauss on the original envelopes of the files has been retained in this finding aid, including the names of correspondents. Untitled files were assigned titles during processing based on format, individual, or general topic. Folders of correspondence with an individual's name that include the word "branch" indicate correspondence that appears to relate to research on this specific branch of the family tree.

Papers in this series primarily include correspondence between Elizabeth Strauss Plaut and her relatives that mention her work on the family genealogy, as well as discussing family news. Other papers consist of family trees, notes on family genealogy, and copies of articles on family members.

Subseries 1 contains papers of the Abraham and Strauss families, and includes information on Elizabeth Strauss Plaut's mother, Therese Abraham Strauss and her grandfather, Victor Abraham. Much of this subseries consists of correspondence on family genealogy and family trees, as well as documentation and notes on branches of the family and individuals.

Several folders in this subseries focus on the life of Therese Abraham Strauss. Among the documentation here are several versions of a memoir by Therese Strauss that describes her childhood and early years. Papers relating to thememoirinclude a foreword and postscript written by Elizabeth Plaut, correspondence regarding its publication by the American Jewish Historical Society, and a précis for a proposed autobiography of Therese Abraham Strauss. Other documentation on her include copies of music critiques, advertisements for her symphony appearances, and professional correspondence. There is also one folder ofletterssent to Therese Strauss by her daughter Elizabeth during the early 1960s.

scopecontent.p: This subseries holds papers related to the Dreyfoos family (spelled alternatively Dreifus, Dreyfus, or Dreifuss), including some of related families such as the Pappenheimers and Guggenheimers. The subseries is comprised of genealogical correspondence and family trees as well as research in the form of notes and photocopied articles.

scopecontent.p: Subseries 3 holds a small amount of papers on the Kline branch of the family, [who were related to the Dreyfoos and Abraham families?]. The majority of papers in this subseries are clippings about the actor Kevin Kline.

Correspondence in this subseries concerns a photograph of Elizabeth Plaut's brother and Robert Kline in front of a passenger train called the Dixie Flyer. Much of the Kline Family Correspondence is between Elizabeth Plaut and Robert Joseph ("Bobby") Kline and provides genealogical information on the connection between the families.
A childhood photograph possibly of Kevin Kline, not originally located among the papers of this subseries, can be found inSeries VI.

did.langmaterial: This subseries is primarily inEnglish, with someGerman.

scopecontent.p: This subseries holds papers relating to the Rauh (spelled alternatively Rau or Raugh) and Mack branches of the family. It is comprised primarily of family trees and correspondence, as well as a significant amount of photocopies of family members' photographs.Correspondencebetween Elizabeth Plaut and Edgar Mack describes the connection between the Rauh and Mack families, as well as their connection to the Pappenheimer and Newbergh families.

did.unittitle: Rauh, Frederick (Fritz) - Correspondence and Family Trees
Rauh, Richard - Family Photographs and Trees

scopecontent.p: Subseries 5 contains papers on the Wertheimer and related branches of the family, such as the Gatz, Rauh, and Rie family branches. It is composed primarily of genealogical and personal correspondence, as well as some family trees and photocopies of newspaper articles on individual family members. Extensive genealogical information will especially be found in the correspondence of Philippe Rie, who was also compiling material on the family history.

did.unittitle: Wertheimer Family - Markus, Edith Sampliner - Correspondence
Wertheimer Family Tree - Rie, Philippe - Correspondence
Wertheimer Family Tree - Rie, Philippe - Wormser Data

scopecontent.p: Subseries 6 is comprised of files relating to the Wisebart branch of Elizabeth Strauss Plaut's family. The correspondence in this subseries is personal in nature, with genealogical matters interspersed among the letters exchanged between Elizabeth Plaut and her relatives. Photocopies of articles on nineteenth-century family members will also be found here. Especially prominent in this subseries is material on Frances Wisebart Jacobs of Colorado, who was included in the National Women's Hall of Fame for her charitable activities.Correspondencewith Emmett Louis includes family trees displaying the connection between the Dreyfoos and Wisebart families.

did.unittitle: Wisebart Data - Correspondence - McGonagle, Clara Jarecki
Wisebart Family Tree - Sampliner Family - Correspondence and Research

arrangement.p:
Separated into the following areas:
A) S & W (Sussman, Wormser & Co.) Fine Foods
B) General Wormser Family

scopecontent.p: Subseries 7 holds files pertaining to the Wormser family, known originally in Germany as the Guggenheim family before the family moved to the town of Aldingen. Papers in Subseries 7 consist of extensive correspondence, numerous family trees, photocopies of articles and historical documents accumulated during Elizabeth Plaut's research on the family, and genealogical notes.

Some of the material in this subseries focuses on the branch of the Wormser family which went to the western United States, settling in such places as San Francisco and Deming, New Mexico. Such files include copies of articles and photographs of these locations. Other papers provide information on Lewis Harris (originally Samuel Wormser), who came to Ireland from Germany and almost became Lord Mayor of Dublin.

Among these papers are several folders that pertain to the history of the S & W Fine Foods company in California, originally begun through a partnership between Samuel Sussman, S.I. Wormser, and Gustav Wormser. Files relating to this branch of the family include some information on the history of the company as well as genealogical material. Included among such papers are family trees and copies of articles on family members descended from this branch of the family and the family residence.

Several memoirs are present in this subseries that provide a view of family member's lives. Among such accounts is a detaileddescriptionby Laurence Klauber of the 1906 San Francisco earthquake and subsequent fire. Thememoirof Marion Israella Blitz describes her childhood and early years in Detroit during the late 1800s. Richard Sommer'srecollectionsmention family members he knew as well as his experiences in Nazi Germany.

Wormser, Samuel (Lewis Harris) - Notes - Jews in Ireland
Series III: General and Unsorted Genealogical Files

scopecontent.p: Series III holds files accumulated during Elizabeth Strauss Plaut's genealogical research. Most of these papers were not identified as belonging to a single branch of the Plaut and Strauss family genealogies. The majority of these files consist of notes taken from various city directories where family members resided. Other files include correspondence with historical institutions. Several folders in this subseries were unidentified, and folder titles were assigned during processing.

Wittenberg Article - The Roots of German Anti-Semitism by Giveon Cornfield

scopecontent.p: Series IV includes several oversized family trees originally separated from the rest of the collection. The series holds seven rolled family trees related to the Strauss side of the family, with Abraham, Dreyfoos, and Strauss family members listed, among others. Two trees relating to the Plaut side of the family are also part of this series.

Series V holds files pertaining to the publication of Elizabeth Strauss Plaut's books and articles, originally found together, primarily in untitled folders. This series includes unpublished manuscripts of texts and family trees, along with correspondence with publishers. Among the manuscripts are both unpublished texts for two of Elizabeth Strauss Plaut's books, as well as copies of shorter articles on genealogical research, some of which were published in the journals Search and Toledot.

A few files pertaining to the publication of The Guggenheim/ Wormser Family: a Genealogical 300-Year Memoir and The Gumprichs of Münster/ Westphalia: a Tale of Four Continents, originally found among the other papers pertaining to their respective families, have been left with the papers of the subseries in which they were originally located.

did.unittitle: Guggenheim/ Wormser Family - Family Trees - from Aldingen, Wuerttemberg, Worms

scopecontent.p: Series VI contains photographs, photocopies of photographs, and a few negatives portraying family members from both Plaut and Strauss sides of the family, as well as invitations and announcements of family events and an unidentified drawing. Most of these papers were found together in untitled folders; most other photographs and photocopies of photographs in this collection have remained among the correspondence and other papers where they were originally filed.

A large, untitled folder with some correspondence, photographs, and notes was divided during processing by family or document format. A few clippings from publications or newspapers featuring photos of family members have also been included in this series. Among the photographs of members of theKline familyis a childhood photograph presumably of the actor, Kevin Kline.

Box 15holds numerous family photographs. These primarily depict individuals and groups of individuals, many of whom are mentioned elsewhere in the collection. Families represented here include the Gumprichs, Hillers, Dreyfooses, Plauts, Pappenheimers, and Strausses.

arrangement.p:
Divided in the following manner:
Subseries 1: Writing, Correspondence, and Notes
Subseries 2: Collected Material

scopecontent.p: Series VII is comprised of papers that do not relate to Elizabeth Straus Plaut's genealogical research. Among the papers found here is a small amount of correspondence, writing, and notes as well as collected papers such as articles and stamps.

Subseries 1 holds non-genealogical papers created by Elizabeth Strauss Plaut or her husband, Rabbi W. Gunther Plaut. Included here are a small amount of personal correspondence, notes, and drafts of lectures and public addresses, short stories, and a play.

Among the papers of this series is one folder of personal correspondence holding five letters sent from Elizabeth Strauss Plaut to her husband during World War II. Other correspondence includes a folder of letters and notes of W. Gunther Plaut, most of which relate to his duties as Rabbi.

Several folders in this series include scripts or notes used for lectures and public addresses. These include the text of a lecture given at a meeting of the National Association of Retired Reform Rabbis (NAORRR) and several folders of notes used by Elizabeth Plaut in invocations for Mount Zion and Holy Temple Sisterhood events, as well as for the installation of organizational officers. This subseries also contains the text of a sermon given on Yom Kippur Eve in 1978, perhaps by W. Gunther Plaut.

Elizabeth Strauss Plaut's creative writing is additionally evidenced in Subseries 1. Found among the papers of this subseries are a short story "Both House and Machine" written by her and her brother William Strauss as well as scripts for the play "The Road Back." Other related papers include correspondence with the publishers ofWorld Overregarding the publication of her short stories as well as an advertisement for the children's game created by Elizabeth Plaut "Holiplay."

scopecontent.p: This small subseries is comprised of material collected by Elizabeth Plaut that does not appear to relate to her genealogical research. Most prominent in this subseries are several folders of Isreali stamps and correspondence with the Israeli Postal Authority Philatelic Services regarding the purchase of Israeli stamps. Other papers found here include two music programs and a few folders of accumulated articles, most relating to scientific or health topics.
